description: Mapping from the column-by-column reading to the half-antidiagonal reading of the triangular tables. Inverse of A056536.
comments: Moves triangular numbers (A000217) to squares (A000290), i.e., A056537(A000217(i)) = A000290(i) for i >= 1.As a square array, this is the dispersion of the complement of the squares; see A082152. - _Clark Kimberling_, Apr 05 2003
links: Ivan Neretin, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..4950
Index entries for sequences that are permutations of the natural numbers
formula: Triangle T(n, k), 1<=k<=n, read by rows, defined by: T(n, k) = 0 for n<k and T(n, k) = A002620(n-k+1) + k*n + k - n if n>=k. T(n, n) = n^2; T(n, 1) = 1 + A002620(n) = A033638(n). - _Philippe Del√©ham_, Feb 16 2004Square: t(n,k) = (n-1)(n+k) + k^2/4 + (1/8)(7+(-1)^k). - _Clark Kimberling_, Aug 08 2013
maple: # using Maple procedure nthmember given in A054426:[seq(nthmember(j, A056536), j=1..105)];
mathematica: (* Program generates the dispersion array T of the increasing sequence f[n] *)r=40; r1=12; c=40; c1=12; f[n_] := n+Floor[1/2+Sqrt[n]] (* complement of column 1 *); mex[list_] := NestWhile[#1 + 1 &, 1, Union[list][[#1]] <= #1 &, 1, Length[Union[list]]]; rows = {NestList[f, 1, c]}; Do[rows = Append[rows, NestList[f, mex[Flatten[rows]], r]], {r}]; t[i_, j_] := rows[[i, j]]; TableForm[Table[t[i, j], {i, 1, r1}, {j, 1, c1}]]  (* A056537 array *)Flatten[Table[t[k, n - k + 1], {n, 1, c1}, {k, 1, n}]] (* A056537 sequence *)(* _Clark Kimberling_, Jun 06 2011 *)
crossrefs: Cf. A185787 (dispersion of complement of triangular numbers).
Cf. A082152 (dispersion of complement of pentagonal numbers).
author: _Antti Karttunen_, Jun 20 2000
